speaker: therapist

vol_text: You're absolutely right, but keep in mind that the food pyramid is to be used as a guideline only. When it comes to nutrition, we have to have a more personalized approach. vol_text: Oh, I understand. Let me ask you this, on a scale from 0 to 10, 0 meaning that there's no way you can do it, and 10 meaning that you're 100% confident that you can do it, how confident are you that you'll be able to reduce the amount of juice you're currently taking in.
speaker: therapist

vol_text: Um, six or seven.
speaker: client

vol_text: All right. So, you're not a zero. So, that tells me that you've got some confidence that this is doable, this is something you certainly can do it. Why are you not a zero?
speaker: therapist

vol_text: I guess it's because I know that I need to do it to lose the weight.
speaker: client

vol_text: So, you realize, again, that if you decrease the amount of juice you're taking in, you're gonna decrease your weight, you're gonna feel better, and you're gonna impact your po- health positively?
speaker: therapist

vol_text: Yes.

vol_text: Hi, Sarah, it's great to meet you. My name is Delwyn, and I'm a counselor here at the clinic. And I heard from your nurse practitioner that you recently had an annual exam in which the topics of smoking and alcohol use came up. Would you mind filling me in a little bit about that?

vol_text: Mm-hmm.

vol_text: Definitely, that's right.

vol_text: All right. Well, um, one of the things I wanted to talk to you about sort of relates to belonging and your friends. So what kinds of things do you like to do when you get together with your friends?

vol_text: Yeah, sometimes.

speaker: therapist

vol_text: Yeah.

vol_text: So it really depends on what the activity is, whether or not alcohol is gonna be there?
speaker: therapist

vol_text: Definitely.
speaker: client

vol_text: Okay. And do you notice a big difference or can you tell me about the difference in your enjoyment level at say a party versus a night you're playing board games?

vol_text: Um, I think of them as-as different, I think, you know, like in playing board games and things, it's meant to be relaxing.

vol_text: Mm-hmm.
speaker: therapist

vol_text: So it's nice to have like that kind of breather-

vol_text: Uh-huh.

vol_text: Mm-hmm.

vol_text: Okay. So there's sort of pros and cons on both sides?
speaker: therapist

vol_text: Yeah.
speaker: client

vol_text: Okay. What are the things that you like about drinking or like about alcohol?

speaker: client

vol_text: Mm-hmm.
speaker: therapist

vol_text: -and not really thinking about stresses or things like that, but it can be--When it's too much drinking, it can be- can be obviously bad.

speaker: client

vol_text: Mm-hmm.

vol_text: -as possible. So we'll like sleep over at a friend's house. And so that, you know, we're not driving and it's mostly within our friend group. So we're not worried about strangers putting weird things in our drinks.

vol_text: Mm-hmm.

vol_text: But, um, definitely some of the ideas people can have when they're stup- when they're drunk and can be really stupid.

vol_text: Yeah

vol_text: It's not.

vol_text: Mm-hmm.
speaker: therapist

vol_text: -and that didn't end well.
speaker: client

vol_text: Mm-hmm.

vol_text: Okay.
